Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Castle Wall Planet
Objects.Notes: A planet made out of stone floors and ruined dark brick walls featuring a high tower.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Lava Tower Planet
Objects.Notes: A large hollow tower planet with inner walls of lava and many stone platforms, Bullet Bill cannons and Banzai Bill cannons.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Dry Ice Planet
Objects.Notes: A planet entirely of deadly dry ice with a large snowy rock column.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Colossal Hollow Lava Planet Interior
Objects.Notes: A standalone variant of the colossal lava planet's interior.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Colossal Hollow Lava Planet Exterior
Objects.Notes: A standalone version of the galaxy-sized hollow spherical lava planet with holes.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Gravity Panel Wall
Objects.Notes: A blue and pink gravity panel wall seen in the Space Junk blocks section.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Small Rotating Sand Brick Circle
Objects.Notes: A small rotating circle of sand brick blocks.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Large Rotating Sand Brick Circle
Objects.Notes: A large rotating circle of sand brick blocks arranged in a zigzag-like pattern.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Rotating Molten Tar Disk
Objects.Notes: A dark rotating disk of molten tar.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Rotating Green Metal Platforms
Objects.Notes: A set of three bent green metal platforms arranged on a circle facing inwards.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Reactor -- Quicksand Planet
Objects.Notes: A planet entirely of deadly quicksand featuring a few sandy platforms.

Objects.Name: Flipbug
Objects.Notes: A small bug-like enemy that attacks the player in Bee form and runs away from the player under normal conditions.

Objects.Name: Goomba
Objects.Notes: The infamous Goomba enemy that appeared in most Mario games since 1985.

Objects.Name: Big Goomba
Objects.Notes: A big Goomba that appears in Gateway Galaxy and the Supermassive Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Fluffy Bluff -- Circular Fence
Objects.Notes: A circular fence that is used in The Chimp's challenge in Fluffy Buff Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Mini Goomba
Objects.Notes: A small round Goomba that drops one Coin when jumped on and a Star Bit if spun (always a Coin in SMG1).

Objects.Name: Long Chain
Objects.Notes: A long chain of configurable length.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Small Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A small platform that sinks into the lava in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Tide Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet used for the secret Star mission.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Tide
Objects.Notes: The lava tide that periodically shrinks and rises.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Large Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A large platform that sinks into the lava in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Dreadnought -- Star Chip Cube Planet
Objects.Notes: The small cube planet that appears on the third star in the Dreadnought Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Battlerock -- Topmaniac's Planet
Objects.Notes: The large UFO planet where Topmaniac is fought in Battlerock Galaxy and Dreadnought Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Dreadnought -- UFO Planet
Objects.Notes: The UFO planet used at the start of the third mission of Dreadnought Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Destroyed UFO
Objects.Notes: A destroyed UFO used in the background of the first mission.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Bridge Segment
Objects.Notes: A small bridge segment that collapses when stepped on.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Gem Boulder
Objects.Notes: A large collapsing boulder consisting of many red gems.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Round Tipping Platform
Objects.Notes: A round tipping rock platform used at the start of the Lava Spire section.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Long Tipping Platform
Objects.Notes: A long tipping rock platform used at the start of the Lava Spire section.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Tipping Stair Platform
Objects.Notes: A tipping rock stair platform used at the start of the Lava Spire section.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Wide Tipping Platform
Objects.Notes: A wide tipping rock platform used at the start of the Lava Spire section.

Objects.Name: Lava Bubble
Objects.Notes: A small bubble of lava that jumps out and back into lava.

Objects.Name: Gravity Gauntlet -- Lava Bubble Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet where you dodge Lava Bubbles and Cheep Cheeps in Bowser's Gravity Gauntlet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- C-Shaped Thwomps Planet
Objects.Notes: The C-shaped planet with several falling meteors and Thwomps.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Star Chip Planet
Objects.Notes: The spherical planet where the player has to collect five Star Chips or defeat five Li'l Cinders in order to progress.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Banzai Bill Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet with Banzai Bills and the Spin Drill used in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Rock Columns A
Objects.Notes: A set of columns used on the Lava Spire planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Rock Columns B
Objects.Notes: A set of columns used on the Lava Spire planet.

Objects.Name: Gravity Gauntlet -- Sinking Trapezoid Platform
Objects.Notes: A trapezoid-shaped platform that sinks when the player stands on it.

Objects.Name: Tiny Purple/Medium Green Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A sinking platform for lava sections. In SMG1 this is a tiny purple platform, in SMG2 it is a medium green platform.

Objects.Name: Medium Green/Big Blue Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A sinking platform for lava sections. In SMG1 this is a medium green platform, in SMG2 it is a big blue platform.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Tall Blue Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A tall blue platform that sinks when stepped on.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Blue Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A blue platform that sinks when stepped on.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Starting Planet
Objects.Notes: The first planet of Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Starting Planet Rotating Platform
Objects.Notes: The rotating platform used on the first planet of Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Lava Geyser
Objects.Notes: A lava geyser used in lava-themed galaxies.

Objects.Name: Gravity Gauntlet -- Starting Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet used at the start of Bowser's Gravity Gauntlet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Long Slanted Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: The long green sinking platform used on the starting planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Starting Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet featuring the tall volcano and several lava ponds.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Sinking Seesaw Platform
Objects.Notes: A pair of two purple sinking platforms that are connected by a huge stone block.

Objects.Name: Falling Volcano Rocks Effect
Objects.Notes: An effect consisting of falling volcano rocks that is used inside Melty Molten Galaxy's volcano.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Volcano Eruption
Objects.Notes: The volcano eruption effect used in Melty Molten Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Rising Volcano Lava
Objects.Notes: The rising lava used inside the volcano.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Main Planet
Objects.Notes: The large lava sphere planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- J-Shaped Planet
Objects.Notes: The large J-shaped planet that features the Bullet Bill cannons.

Objects.Name: Gusty Garden -- Hedge Maze Planet
Objects.Notes: The hedge maze planet where the player has to chase a Star Bunny.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Meteors Planet
Objects.Notes: The long planet that features Star Chips and several falling meteors.

Objects.Name: Mini Lava Planet
Objects.Notes: A small spherical lava planet used in the background of lava-themed galaxies or sections, including Melty Molten Galaxy and Freezeflame Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- UFO Planet
Objects.Notes: The UFO planet visited during the first and third missions.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Ground Pound Platform
Objects.Notes: The big movable Ground Pound platform used on the starting planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Falling Rock Blockade
Objects.Notes: A falling stone block that blocks the Wall Jump section on the starting planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Ground Pound Parts
Objects.Notes: The big movable Ground Pound parts used on the Lava Spire planet.

Objects.Name: Fireball
Objects.Notes: A fireball used in lava-themed galaxies.

Objects.Notes: A large rotating fireball with a long trail; used in Melty Molten Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Fireballs [Group of Three]
Objects.Notes: A group of three rotating fireballs with long trails; used in Melty Molten Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Fireball without Shadow
Objects.Notes: A fireball with no shadow; used in Melty Molten Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Rotating Lava Planet
Objects.Notes: The large rotating lava planet visited in the third mission.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Rotating Lava Planet Fixed Platform
Objects.Notes: The stationary platform used on the rotating lava planet.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- 2D Star Chips Planet
Objects.Notes: The 2D planet with several colorful rotating platforms and five Star Chips.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Set of Red Rotating Platforms
Objects.Notes: A set of four red rotating platforms used on the 2D planet with the Star Chips.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Pair of Orange Rotating Platforms
Objects.Notes: A pair of orange rotating platforms used on the 2D planet with the Star Chips.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Set of Green Rotating Platforms
Objects.Notes: A set of four green rotating platforms used on the 2D planet with the Star Chips.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Pair of Yellow Rotating Platforms
Objects.Notes: A pair of yellow rotating platforms used on the 2D planet with the Star Chips.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Crushing Lava Walls
Objects.Notes: A set of two lava walls that move to crush Mario. Used in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Lava Spire Starting Platform

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Short Decorative Lava Rock
Objects.Notes: A short lava rock used in the background of the Pull Star section.

Objects.Name: Large Lava Sparks Effect
Objects.Notes: A large lava sparks particle effect.

Objects.Name: Small Lava Sparks Effect
Objects.Notes: A small lava sparks particle effect.

Objects.Name: Lava Steam
Objects.Notes: A hole that periodically emits hot steam that burns the player upon contact.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Small Generic Platform
Objects.Notes: A small generic rock platform used throughout the level.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Medium Generic Platform
Objects.Notes: A medium generic rock platform used throughout the level.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Large Generic Platform
Objects.Notes: A large generic rock platform used throughout the level.

Objects.Notes: A small stalagmite seen in the background of some sections.

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Large Stalagmite

Objects.Name: Melty Molten -- Stalagmite Platform
Objects.Notes: An unused stalagmite platform.

Objects.Notes: A small transparent planet used in Melty Molten Galaxy and Snow Cap Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Freezeflame -- Moving Lava Layer
Objects.Notes: The moving lava layer found on the ice and lava planet.

Objects.Name: Freezeflame -- Ice & Lava Planet Lava Side

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Dash Pepper Planet Sinking Platform
Objects.Notes: A circular sinking platform used on the Dash Pepper planet in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Name: Galaxy Generator -- Dash Pepper Planet
Objects.Notes: The planet where the Dash Pepper is found in Bowser's Galaxy Generator.

Objects.Notes: A moving leaf raft used in Starshine Beach Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Flipsville -- Red Grate
Objects.Notes: A red grate that can be flipped over; used in Flipsville Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: An area that causes a lens flare on the camera when entered.

Objects.Notes: An area that changes lighting when entered.

Objects.Name: Light Area [Cylinder]
Objects.Notes: An area that changes lighting when entered.

Objects.Notes: Mario's younger brother who offers to play a level in Mario's place when talked to.

Objects.Notes: A yellow tile used on the Comet of Mario Squared Galaxy, instead of the Flipswitches.

Objects.Name: Luigi NPC
Objects.Notes: Mario's younger brother who can be talked to.

Objects.Name: Ringing Bell
Objects.Notes: A shiny bell that can be rung to activate a switch.

Objects.Name: Shiverburn -- Starting Planet [Frozen]

Objects.Name: Shiverburn -- Starting Planet [Flaming]

Objects.Name: Shiverburn -- Stone Rock B
Objects.Notes: A large stone rock used in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A large stone rock used in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A large stone rock used in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A lava meteor that creates a lava pond once it lands; used on the skating planet in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: The large volcano planet used in the first mission of Melty Monster Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A set of rotating platforms used on the lava platforms planet in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A set of rotating platforms used on the lava platforms planet in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A set of rotating platforms used on the lava platforms planet in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Notes: A set of rotating platforms used on the lava platforms planet in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Banzai Bill Spawner
Objects.Notes: Generates larger versions of Bullet Bills.

Objects.Name: The Chimp [Skating Challenge]
Objects.Notes: The Chimp NPC used for the skating challenges in both Freezy Flake Galaxy and Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Skate Challenge Controller [Freezy Flake]
Objects.Notes: A controller used to control The Chimp's skating challenge in Freezy Flake Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Skate Challenge Controller [Shiverburn]
Objects.Notes: A controller used to control The Chimp's skating challenge in Shiverburn Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Deep Dark -- Watermelon Glass Cage Planet
Objects.Notes: A glass planet with orange balls and a watermelon trapped inside. The watermelon grows by smashing these orange balls into it.

Objects.Name: Underwater Plant
Objects.Notes:
A decorative plant for underwater sections. There is only one shape model, so ShapeModelNo has to be set to 0. The available texture frames are:
- 0 Lime
- 1 Red
- 2 Wavy, green
- 3 Orange
- 4 Smooth, green

Objects.Name: Spawn Point
Objects.Notes: Sets the spawn point for the player at the start of a mission or at Checkpoints in a mission.

Objects.Name: Mario/Luigi
Objects.Notes: Creates a clone of the player that can be controlled. May also be used as the actual spawn point. Should not be used in actual levels!

Objects.Name: Enter New World Cutscene Object Holder
Objects.Notes: A holder that creates and registers several objects that are used in the cutscene where Starship Mario takes off to a new world after collecting a Grand Star.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario Intro Cutscene Holder
Objects.Notes: A holder that registers and stores the cutscenes that are used for entering/accessing the Starship Mario through various means.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Fruit Planet
Objects.Notes: A small disk-shaped planet containing fruit; used on Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Main Planet before Transformation
Objects.Notes: The damaged planet that gets transformed into Starship Mario at the beginning of the game.

Objects.Name: First World Map Entrance Cutscene Object Holder
Objects.Notes: A holder that creates and registers several objects that are used in the cutscene where Starship Mario takes off to World 1 for the first time.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Decorative Chimney
Objects.Notes: The chimney used on Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Rocket Booster
Objects.Notes: A rocket booster used on the back of Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario Object Appearance Event Setup
Objects.Notes: Sets up a short camera sequence for Starship Mario in which Lubba explains a newly appeared object on the Starship, such as items or NPCs.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Main Planet
Objects.Notes: The main planet that makes up the Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario -- Blue Core
Objects.Notes: The blue core used in the power-up display room of Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Starship Mario Steering Wheel
Objects.Notes: The steering wheel used on Starship Mario.

Objects.Name: Player Cannon
Objects.Notes: A cannon that the player can use to shoot themselves to distant places.

Objects.Name: Player Cannon Gravity
Objects.Notes: A gravity area that attracts the player towards its center point while they are being launched from a cannon.

Objects.Name: Battlerock -- Trapped Luma Interior Section
Objects.Notes: The large interior section where the player has to free a Luma that is trapped inside a crystal.

Objects.Name: Boom Bunker -- Hammer Bros. Planet Cannon Target
Objects.Notes: A target for a cannon used on the Hammer Bros. planet in Bowser Jr.'s Boom Bunker.

Objects.Name: Boom Bunker -- Cloud Ferris Wheel Planet Cannon Target
Objects.Notes: A target for a cannon used on the cloud Ferris wheel planet in Bowser Jr.'s Boom Bunker.

Objects.Name: Boom Bunker -- Dark Matter Planet Cannon Target
Objects.Notes: A target for a cannon used on the Dark Matter planet in Bowser Jr.'s Boom Bunker.

Objects.Notes: An area that hides Mario's cap when entered.

Objects.Notes: Mecha-Bowser's left arm that features a claw-like hand.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Right Mecha-Bowser Arm
Objects.Notes: Mecha-Bowser's right arm that features several green panels.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Mecha-Bowser Body
Objects.Notes: The main body parts, legs and lower platforms that belong to the colossal Mecha-Bowser.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Mecha-Bowser Panel
Objects.Notes: A large green panel that covers the inside of the colossal Mecha-Bowser.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Mecha-Bowser Conveyor Belt
Objects.Notes: The moving conveyor belt planet where Mecha-Bowser is located.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Rotating Mecha-Bowser Collar
Objects.Notes: The large rotating collar with spikes that belongs to Mecha-Bowser.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Mecha-Bowser Head
Objects.Notes: The head and upper platforms that belong to the colossal Mecha-Bowser.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Moving Mecha-Bowser Platform
Objects.Notes: A blue moving platform that acts as an elevator on Mecha-Bowser's planet.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Mecha-Bowser Foot Wheel
Objects.Notes: One of Mecha-Bowser's many animated wheels that can crush the player.

Objects.Name: Toy Time -- Stationary Left Mecha-Bowser Arm
Objects.Notes: A non-rotating and metal version of Mecha-Bowser's left arm that is not used in the actual level.

Objects.Name: Mecha-Koopa
Objects.Notes: A small robotic version of a Koopa that can be defeated by Ground Pounding it.

Objects.Name: Bowser's First Appearance Cutscene Object Holder
Objects.Notes: A holder that creates and registers several objects that are used in the cutscene where Bowser is encountered for the first time in Peach's Castle.

Objects.Name: Lubba

Objects.Name: Flash Black Sky

Objects.Name: Flash Black -- Silver Star Platforms
Objects.Notes: The planet where the Silver Stars are located in the first mission of Flash Black Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Flash Black -- Mansion Planet
Objects.Notes: The large mansion planet used at the start of Flash Black Galaxy.

Objects.Name: Skeeter
Objects.Notes: A purple spider that lunges across water.

Objects.Name: Li'l Cinder
Objects.Notes: A burning rock enemy that floats around and chases after Mario. It will burn the player upon contact. If attacked with a Fire Ball, it gets reignited.

Objects.Name: Mercator Projection Area [Cube]
Objects.Notes: A special area that projects compatible objects inside it around the origin of the zone.

Objects.Name: Generic Fixed Mercator Map Object [Unused]
Objects.Notes: A stationary object that uses Mercator projection for placement. It retrieves a proper model using ShapeModelNo, however, no more models exist for this object.

Objects.Name: Generic Moving Mercator Map Object [Unused]
Objects.Notes: A path-moving object that uses Mercator projection for placement. It retrieves a proper model using ShapeModelNo, however, no more models exist for this object.

Objects.Name: Generic Rotating Mercator Map Object [Unused]
Objects.Notes: A rotating object that uses Mercator projection for placement. It retrieves a proper model using ShapeModelNo, however, no more models exist for this object.

Objects.Notes: This area forces to display the linked shouting messages when entered.

Objects.Name: Display Message Area [Cylinder]
Objects.Notes: This area forces to display the linked shouting messages when entered.

Objects.Name: Boo Picture
Objects.Notes:
A picture of a Boo or Bomb Boo. The TexChange frame IDs for the different pictures are:
0 Boo
1 Empty
2 Bomb Boo

Objects.Notes: The gloomy planet with dead trees where the Spooky Speedster challenges the player.

Objects.Notes: A ? Block that gives one Star Bit every time it is hit. Disappears after some hits and seconds.

Objects.Notes: A switch that appears another switch after the requested number of frames elapsed.

Objects.Notes: A brown treasure chest that reveals a Star Chip when opened.

SW_A.Description: If used, the object starts moving when this switch is activated. This switch will be ignored if it registered a cutscene nerve action.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

DemoCast.Description: Can take part in a cutscene. Its special cutscene nerve action makes it start moving.

SW_DEAD.Description: Can be activated when the object is killed through a cutscene action.

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model and collision that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided.
Classes.Name: AnmModelSwitchMove

SW_A.Description: If used, the object starts moving when this switch is activated. This switch will be ignored if it registered a cutscene nerve action.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

DemoCast.Description: Can take part in a cutscene. Its special cutscene nerve action makes it start moving.

SW_DEAD.Description: Gets activated once the object kills itself.

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model and collision that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. Once the Move.bck animation has ended, the object will kill itself. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. AnmModelKill specifies the sound effect used when it kills itself. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.
Classes.Name: AnmModelSwitchMoveEndKill

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model and collision that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. Once any of the Move animations has ended, the object will kill itself. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. AnmModelKill specifies the sound effect used when it kills itself. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model and collision that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. Additionally, the collision will be disabled once it has moved once. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model and collision that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. Additionally, the collision will be disabled until it has moved. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model, collision and a Move.bva visibility animation that will play its Move animations once certain conditions are met. The Move.bva animation's initial frame will be used until the conditions are met. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Classes.Notes: A generic object with a model, collision and a Reverse.brk animation that will play its Move and Reverse.brk animations once certain conditions are met. The Reverse.brk animation's last frame will be used until the conditions are met. It uses several sound effects. AnmModelMoveStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts moving. AnmModelMoveLoop specifies the looping sound effect that is played while it moves. AnmModelStop specifies the sound effect used when it stops moving. AnmModelReverse specifies the sound effect used when the Reverse.brk animations starts playing. Furthermore, it can use several particle effects as well. Start specifies the particles used when it starts moving. EndLoop specifies the particles used after it stopped moving. It can also shake the screen and rumble the player's Wiimote if a proper PadAndCameraCtrl file is provided. Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.
Classes.Name: AnmModelSwitchSyncBrk

Classes.Notes: A flying bat enemy. These enemies may be flying around passively, move on a path or hang from ceilings. If the player comes within its range, it will fly towards them to attack. The icy variant (BasaBasaIce) will freeze the player if touched, provided that they are not using the Ice power-up. It can be defeated using Spin Attacks, Stomping and most other attacks. It can be stunned by shooting Star Bits at them. The icy variant (BasaBasaIce) can be attacked if the player has the Ice power-up.

Classes.Notes: A large stone block boss. He can summon Whimps that will try to attack the player like Whomps do. The boss himself can defeat those smaller blocks by crushing them. Like his smaller counterparts, this boss will try to fall onto the player to attack them. He can also attack using shockwaves that appear when he jumps. When he's lying on ground, the player can Ground Pound the weak spot on its back to damage him. After hitting the boss three times, he will be defeated. He always spawns a Power Star.

She is supposed to be placed on a disk-like planet as she can freely walk around such planets and change sides. She always spawns a Power Star which needs to be set up in the galaxy's Scenario file.

After dealing three hits, he will spawn a Power Star. This requires an edit to the galaxy's Scenario file.

While it flies, it will periodically drop explosive bombs that can hurt the player. After it is defeated, it will spawn a Power Star, which also requires changes to the galaxy's Scenario file.

Classes.Notes:
A generic map object that will turn invisible if the camera passes it. For this, it loads a separate model with the suffix Alpha. The Alpha model uses two animations. Normal.brk, which is used for the visible state, and Alpha.brk, which is used to make the model fade out of existence.
It also supports BCK, BTK, BTP, BRK and BVA animations. Animations must have the same name as the model in order to be played. The animations will start playing once the object loads. Also supports color change (ColorChange.brk) and texture change (TexChange.btk/.btk) animations as well as shadows (Shadow.bcsv). Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.
Classes.Name: ChangeAlphaObj

After this event, it will become usable. In order to open the door, its SW_A needs to be activated. If it is registered to a cutscene called , it can use a special nerve action which cause the player to jump out.

Classes.Notes: One of the game's main collectibles. There are two variants: Coins (Coin) and Purple Coins (PurpleCoin). Normal Coins can restore one health point if collected by the player. Purple Coins do not restore health, though. Purple Coins can only be used in Purple Comet scenarios or appropriately configured Scenario files. Normal Coins won't appear during Daredevil (Dark) Comets. If they are stored inside a bubble, they will also restore the player's air when underwater. Spins slower when placed underwater.

Obj_arg3.Description: Contexts that are affected by camera changes through this area. In SMG2, these values can be combined by adding the values together. If set to 0, the game will set this value to 1. In SMG1, this setting is much more complicated: The lower four bits can be used to specify a single category (0 = Normal, 1 = Underwater, ...). These bits will be ignored if bit 4 or higher is set. These upper bits then correspond to bit field values (16 = Normal, 32 = Underwater, ...).

The corresponding camera ID label is generated using the format string c:%04x. For example, if your camera area has an Obj_arg0 of 15, the corresponding ID label would be c:000f. The camera can be restricted to take effect only under different circumstances (Obj_arg3).

TimeSheetName refers to the set of cutscene config files to be used and DemoName is the proper identifier name for the cutscene. DemoName should match the cutscene's identifier that it belongs to. The following cutscenes will be registered:  for starting from the file select,  for the normal ending, 120 for collecting all 120 normal Power Stars,  for returning from a World Map,  for collecting the first Power Star in Sky Station Galaxy and  for restarting after a Game Over.

Classes.Notes: A Piranha Plant boss that resides inside its small egg before the battle starts. The player has to destroy its eggshell to reveal its large weak point. It can be damaged using Ground Pounds and Spin Attacks. Ground Pounding the shell from above will remove the entire shell at once. When its shell has been removed, it will run around in panic. The player has to repeat this procedure again to defeat it. It always damages the player upon contact. It will always spawn a Power Star when defeated, which requires a properly configured Scenario entry.

It always damages the player upon contact. However, the large tail ball does not hurt the player. In SMG1, it will always spawn a Power Star when defeated, which requires a properly configured Scenario entry.

It always damages the player upon contact. However, the large tail ball does not hurt the player unless it's burning. It will sporadically shoot fireballs during the last phase and create fiery trails that burn the player upon contact. It will always spawn a Power Star when defeated, which requires a properly configured Scenario entry.

It also creates trails of dirt when it moves around. He is usually underground but can be stunned using a Ground Pound when his head is above the ground. This gives the player a chance to attack him. In SMG1, it always spawns a Power Star and uses text for the Star Bunny it chases.

Classes.Notes: A generic particles effect with a clipping radius of 1000 units and a far clipping distance of 50 meters. Furthermore, its clipping center is at (0, 200, 0). EffectEmitStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts functioning. EffectEmitting specifies the looping sound effect that is played while particles are emitting.

There has to be one RailObj instance for each of the two points which have to be linked to this object.

The path defines its shape, and it can be split into several smaller segments which also creates some gaps. It cannot be destroyed without special triggers.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Path_arg5.Name: Snapping Speed

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Values.Notes: Draw dots but disappear one by one when passed by
Use bigger dots for path points

Classes.Notes: A map object with a model and optional collision that usually moves on a set path. Once it starts moving, it emits its MoveStart particles. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, and RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animations Move and RailMoveSign; the latter would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior. Lastly, it can also use the stage effects Start, Moving, and Stop.
Classes.Name: FallDownWall

Classes.Notes: A tall water fountain that consists of a model and particles. If the player touches it, they will be flung upwards. The water fountain will disappear and reappear periodically.

Classes.Notes: A generic planet with a model and optional collision that also supports fur maps. The normal collision mesh has the same name as the object itself. However, it also supports WaterSurface and MoveLimit collision meshes. If the model has a joint named Move, the collision will be set to follow that joint. Furthermore, it can also use particle effects and sounds. Planets support optional Water, Indirect, Bloom, Low and Middle models. As PlanetMap already supports fur maps in SMG2, FurPlanetMap is rather redundant in this game.
Classes.Name: FurPlanetMap

If the player is too far away from this object, it will become inactive and the player cannot point at it. It usually remains stationary but can move on a path as well. The player can be ejected while using the Pull Star if he gets to close to it, although this is an optional setting.

It does not appear in a level until the selected mission has been cleared with Luigi already. The GST motion data for it can be found in the gst folder of the Galaxy's Ghost archive. It uses a different execution and drawing order in MagicGalaxy and the second mission of StarCreekGalaxy.

Classes.Notes: A darkness model used to cover major portions of the screen except of a cutout showing the player character. It will always be invisible until SW_A gets activated. The model will briefly disappear when an event camera is active. After that it will reappear again.

Classes.Notes: A variant of SimpleMapObj that gets rendered after most other objects. This is a generic map object with a model and collision. It also supports BCK, BTK, BTP, BRK and BVA animations. Animations must have the same name as the model in order to be played. The animations will start playing once the object loads. Also supports color change (ColorChange.brk) and texture change (TexChange.btk/.btp) animations as well as shadows (Shadow.bcsv). Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Obj_arg1.Description: Adjusts the inwards pull distance. This essentially specifies the gravity angle towards the center axis. For example, if this value is 800 and the distance to the center axis is 900, the resulting angle towards the center axis is 45. This is because min(45, 800/900 * 180/pi). Default is -1 which disables inwards pulling.
Obj_arg1.Name: Inwards Pull Distance

Obj_arg0.Description: Read but never used for anything. Default is 500.
Obj_arg0.Name: Useless

Classes.Notes: A platform that can move on a path, rotate or do both. It features two color animations. Normal.brk is used normally and Change.brk is used when its SW_B gets activated. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RotatorRotateStart, RotatorRotateLoop, RotatorStopAtEnd, RotatorStopAtEndLoop, RotatorRotateSignStart, RotatorRotateSignLoop, RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, and RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animation RailMoveSign that would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior.

Classes.Notes: An object with a model and collision that can be Ground Pounded to move it away from its initial position. The distance, required Ground Pounds and more can be configured. Initially, the object can only be Ground Pounded from the bottom side of the model to move it upwards. It can play various different sounds: Start, Moving, StopEnd and Stop, all of which are self-explanatory. Interestingly, the class offers an unused functionality where one or more buttons (HipDropMoveBlockSwitch) can be attached to the object that will cause the object to move when one of the buttons has been stomped. The positions and offsets can be defined in a file called InitHipDropMoveBlockSwitch.bcsv. The actual model for the button actor does not exist anymore and needs to be restored. Unfortunately, the button does not take the object's rotation into account when placed.
Classes.Name: HipDropMoveBlock

If the Spiny has been killed, it will throw another one. It can be defeated using most of the player's attacks, and it can be eaten by Yoshi. However, it will respawn after a while. At least one Spiny should be linked to it, otherwise it won't throw any Spiny.

This fully expands its spring head. It is not possible to destroy it through any means.

Classes.Notes: A Koopa Troopa that can cast various magical spells. The object's name declares what spells it casts. If the object's name is FireBallBeamKameck (SMG1) or Kameck (SMG2), it will cast fireballs. If the object's name is TurtleBeamKameck (SMG1), it will cast sliding Koopa Shells. SMG2 features two more variants: KameckKuriboMini and KameckMeramera which create Mini Goombas and Li'l Cinders, respectively. It moves between path points or stays at a fixed position. After casting a spell, it will temporarily disappear. It can be defeated using most of the player's attacks as well as explosions. It drops a single Coin when defeated.

Furthermore, the final encounter also requires AttackRockFinal, KoopaFinalStarPlanet and KoopaFinalBattlePos. Additionally, it requires a specific cutscene setup. Classes.Notes: A generic planet with a model and optional collision intended to be used for Bowser battle setups. It automatically registers to the accessor of Bowser battle setup objects. It can also register any object linked to it. The appearance and disappearance of the linked objects will be synchronized with this object. The normal collision mesh has the same name as the object itself. However, it also supports WaterSurface and MoveLimit collision meshes. If the model has a joint named Move, the collision will be set to follow that joint. Furthermore, it can also use particle effects and sounds. Planets support optional Water, Indirect, Bloom, Low and Middle models as well as fur maps.
Classes.Name: KoopaBattlePlanet

Classes.Notes: A bug-like enemy that remains idle until the player approaches it. If the player has the Bee power-up, it will chase after the player to damage them. Otherwise, it will flee from the player before dropping on its back after a while. This can be accomplished by attacking it with most of the player's attacks as well. Attacking it again will defeat it. However, it can be instantly defeated using a Ground Pound, the Rainbow power-up and the player's fireballs. Usually, it reveals three Star Bits when defeated. However, it drops a Coin when Ground Pounded or stomped.
Classes.Name: KoteBug

MarioFaceShipNpcRegister.Description: Can be registered to a Starship Mario object appearance event.

Message.Description: The text dialogue's label format is Meister%03d, where %03d is the text message ID. Additionally, it will use various complex dialogues from SceneCommonMessage. If Obj_arg0 is set, it will also load dialogues for the special appearance events from SceneCommonMessage.

BranchFunc.Description: Object-specific behavior for BranchFunc branch flow nodes.

Values.Notes: Number of cleared Power Stars is even?

YoshiTargetable.Description: Can be targeted and licked by Yoshi.

DemoSimpleCast.Description: Continues movement during cutscenes, NPC conversations, etc.

SW_DEAD.Description: Can be activated when the object is killed through a cutscene action.

Obj_arg0.Description: If set, it will register and register to various Starship Mario events. This is only read if the current stage is MarioFaceShipGalaxy.
Obj_arg0.Name: Registers Starship Events?

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: The large purple Luma NPC that can be talked to. It registers to various Starship Mario cutscenes and events.
Classes.Name: Meister

SW_A.Description: Makes the doors open once activated.

Classes.Notes: A pair of closed doors that can be opened. It also flashes depending on the background music's beat.
Classes.Name: MemoryRoadDoor

ClippingGroup.Description: Objects in this group are always clipped together.

Classes.Notes: A generic map object with a model and collision. It also supports loading a model based on its ShapeModelNo. It will flash depending on the background music's beat.
Classes.Name: MemoryRoadStep

Obj_arg7.Description: Specifies how far down it looks for the collision that limits its movement. Default is 1000.
Obj_arg7.Name: Move Limit Collision Detection Distance

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

DemoCast.Description: Tries to register to the cutscene with the name  which is used in Cosmic Cove Galaxy when the main planet gets frozen.

YoshiTargetable.Description: Can be targeted and eaten by Yoshi.

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted, frozen and defeated by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A spider-like enemy that lunges across water. When it touches ice collision, it will be frozen to ice. It can be defeated by stomping, Spin Attacks, Ground Pounding, Yoshi's projectiles, Koopa Shells and explosions.
Classes.Name: Menbo

MoveLimitCollision.Description: The collision binder also checks for MoveLimit collision.

Obj_arg0.Description: Specifies its initial behavior.
Obj_arg0.Name: Initial Behavior

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted, frozen and attacked (SMG2 only) by player 2.

Obj_arg2.Description: If set, it'll keep respawning when killed.
Obj_arg2.Name: Respawns?

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: An enemy that can damage the player upon contact. Can be stunned with a Spin Attack which reveals its core. The core can be destroyed by most of Mario's actions.
Classes.Name: Meramera

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Obj_arg0.Description: The radius of the sphere that the objects will get projected on.
Obj_arg0.Name: Projection Radius

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: A special area that projects compatible objects inside it onto a sphere around the zone's origin. The area's initial placement will be used for the calculations. Therefore, the switches are effectively useless.
Classes.Name: MercatorTransformCube

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Obj_arg0.Description: The message link ID of the shouting messages that should be displayed. Not to be confused with the MessageId of an object.
Obj_arg0.Name: Message Link ID

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: An area that forcibly displays all linked shouting messages when entered.
Classes.Name: MessageArea

MoveLimitCollision.Description: The collision binder also checks for MoveLimit collision.

SW_A.Description: If used, it will move around only if this switch is activated.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

YoshiTargetable.Description: Can be targeted and eaten by Yoshi.

ClippingGroup.Description: Objects in this group are always clipped together.

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted, frozen and attacked (SMG2 only) by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A Goomba wearing a metal helmet. Therefore, they have to be stunned with a Spin Attack first before the player can stomp its weak spot. However, they can be defeated using the Rainbow power-up, Yoshi's projectiles or by having Yoshi eat them. It drops a Coin or three Star Bits depending on how it was defeated.
Classes.Name: Metbo

Rail.Description: The path that the meteors move on.

Obj_arg1.Description: The spawn delay of the individual meteors in seconds. Needs to be a positive number.
Obj_arg1.Name: Spawn Delay

Obj_arg0.Description: The rate at which the meteors fall. Default is 10.
Obj_arg0.Name: Fall Speed

Obj_arg2.Description: If set, multiple meteors can move on the path at the same time.
Obj_arg2.Name: Allow Multiple Meteors?

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: A spawner for meteors that will crumble once they hit collision or the player. They damage the player upon contact. However, MeteorStrikeEnvironment does not interact with the player. If the object is called MeteorStrike, the meteors will only spawn if the spawner object is out of view. If the object is called MeteorCannon, the camera will shake once a meteor crumbles. For some reason, MeteorStrikeEnvironment crashes the game if a meteor hits collision.
Classes.Name: MeteorStrikeLauncher

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: An area that causes compatible objects inside it to create a mirrored model. The mirrored models are usually rendered onto SimpleMirrorObj instances.
Classes.Name: MirrorArea

YoshiTargetable.Description: Can be targeted by Yoshi.

AppearPowerStar.Description: Gets spawned after triggering its EventFunc.

Obj_arg1.Name: Spawns Power Star?

Obj_arg0.Description: The shape to use.
Obj_arg0.Name: Shape

SW_APPEAR.Description: Very buggy so it shouldn't be used. The object will appear when this switch is activated, but it will always have appeared even if the switch is deactivated. Deactivating the switch again will fix this, though.

Classes.Notes: A strange wood NPC that can be talked to.
Classes.Name: Moc

SW_A.Description: If used, it will only turn to the player and throw wrenches while this switch is activated.

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Obj_arg0.Description: If set, the wrench that it throws won't be affected by gravity.
Obj_arg0.Name: Disable Wrench Gravity?

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted and frozen by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A mole enemy that hides in its hatch if the player is too far away or too close to it. If the player is nearby, it will come out of its hatch, and it will try to attack the player by throwing wrenches at them. It can be stunned by shooting a Star Bit at it or by Ground Pounding nearby. When stunned, it can be defeated using most of the player's attacks. If the stage's name is CannonFleetGalaxy, it will use a greater range in which it can detect the player.
Classes.Name: Mogu

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Rail.Description: The path that it moves on.

Obj_arg0.Description: The rate at which it moves on the path. Default is 5.
Obj_arg0.Name: Movement Speed

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted and frozen by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A mole enemy that moves on a set path. The player takes damage by touching it. It can be stunned by Ground Pounding nearby which makes it vulnerable to Spin Attacks. However, it can be defeated with any player attacks, such as fireballs and Koopa Shells.
Classes.Name: Mogucchi

SW_A.Description: If used, it won't shoot projectiles while this switch is not activated. Furthermore, its clipping will be toggled when this switch's state changes.

Obj_arg0.Description: The delay between shots. Default is 90.
Obj_arg0.Name: Launch Delay

Player2Targetable.Description: Can be targeted and frozen by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A mole enemy that uses a floating cannon to shoot cannonballs at the player. If the object's name is KillerShooter, it will shoot Bullet Bills instead. It can be defeated using Yoshi's projectiles or explosions.
Classes.Name: MogucchiShooter

Classes.Notes: If the player stays inside this area and fulfills the specified conditions (Obj_arg0), it will activate its SW_A switch. If the player leaves the area again or the condition is not met anymore, the switch will be deactivated again. If Obj_arg0 is set to 1, it will check if the player is "in rush". This refers to the state where the player is bound to another object, for example Fluzzard, Rock Mushroom's rolling rock, the Star Ball and more.
Classes.Name: MorphSwitchArea

SW_B.Description: Gets activated when it lands on a blue cross face.

SW_A.Description: Gets activated when it lands on a red circle face.

Classes.Notes: A die block that activates a switch depending on the side it lands on when hit. The player can hit it using Spin Attacks, Star Bits, snowballs, fireballs, Yoshi's projectiles and the Rock power-up.
Classes.Name: MultipleChoiceDice

SW_A.Description: If activated, the vanish animations will be played.

Classes.Notes: A collision-less cake planet that is wrapped inside a present box. It uses the two animations BoxVanish and CakeVanish, which cause the box and cake to vanish if SW_A is activated. If the player is within 3000 units while the object is being initialized, the cake will automatically vanish.
Classes.Name: MysteryMountainPlanet

Classes.Notes: A spiky plant that damages the player when touched. It can be destroyed with fireballs, Yoshi's projectiles, the Rock power-up and the Rainbow power-up, Coconuts and Stretch Plants.

Classes.Notes: A frog-like enemy that jumps and burrows into the ground. If it does so, it will reappear out of a random spot again. They will try to pick up an item if they find one and run away with it. It can pick up Coins, Purple Coins, Silver Stars, Star Chips and Blue Chips. They can be defeated by having Yoshi eat them or by stomping on top of them. However, they will reappear again after a few seconds.

The player can bounce off its shell. If performed several consecutive times, the player will be awarded a 1-Up on every bounce.

Classes.Notes: Creates and registers several objects that appear during the ending cutscene where Rosalina visits Starship Mario. The individual models that it creates are DemoMarioFaceShipPlanet, WorldMapAccessPanel, MarioFaceShipRudder, DemoAstroCocoon, DemoAstroPlanet, TicoBaby, Peach, Rosetta, Meister, and GrandStar. Some joints of the models MarioShipTakeOff and DemoAstroPlanetNull are used to position the other models.
Classes.Name: NormalEndingDemoObj

Obj_arg1.Description: How fast the creator note moves along the path. Requires Obj_arg3 set to any value between 1 and 6 inclusive. Default is 13.
Obj_arg1.Name: Appearance Speed

Obj_arg0.Description: If set to -1, the necessary notes to play the song will be created. If set to -2, notes will be placed on path points only. Any other positive number specifies how many notes should be spawned, however, this number is ignored when Obj_arg4 is not negative.
Obj_arg0.Name: Number of Notes

Obj_arg3.Description: Specifies how the individual notes appear and whether a short cutscene should be played or not.

Values.Notes: Single note appears, moves along path and creates other notes, starts appearance camera
Single note appears, moves along path and creates other notes, starts appearance camera
Single note moves on path and creates trail of notes, cutscene runs until all notes have appeared
Notes appear one by one, starts appearance camera
Notes appear one by one, no appearance jingle plays

Obj_arg3.Name: Appearance Type

Obj_arg2.Description: How long it takes before the notes disappear again. Default is 20.
Obj_arg2.Name: Time Limit

Path_arg0.Description: Specifies how long each note play out. Only used when Obj_arg0 is set to -2.
Path_arg0.Name: Note Play Length

Classes.Notes: A tube worm-like enemy that opens its eyes and tries to block the player's movement when approached. When the player touches it, they'll be damaged. It can be defeated with a Koopa Shell or by the light shone by the shell itself. Furthermore, the player can use Spin Attacks or Star Bits to defeat it. This causes it to drop three Star Bits.
Classes.Name: Nyoropon

DemoCast.Description: Can take part in a cutscene. The object won't appear until this cutscene causes it to do so through a cutscene action.

DemoSimpleCast.Description: Continues movement during cutscenes, NPC conversations, etc. Only works if the object isn't already part of another cutscene.

Classes.Notes: A sphere of water that essentially functions as a visible WaterArea. If the stage's name is TearDropGalaxy, it becomes translucent and uses a lighter shade of blue; if the stage's name is SkullSharkGalaxy, it retains the dark blue color but becomes translucent as well. When it appears through a cutscene, the water will scale up first.
Classes.Name: OceanSphere

Classes.Notes: Creates and registers several objects that appear during the opening cutscene where Mario receives the letter from Peach and appears through a Warp Pipe. The object's placement specifies where the Warp Pipe appears from. The individual models that it creates are PeachShootingStar, PeachPrologueSky, and EarthenPipe. Furthermore, it uses the layouts PrologueText and PeachLetterMini. Before the player appears, the music STM_SMG2_EV_PROLOGUE_02 starts to play.

Player2Targetable.Description: Its coconuts can be targeted and fetched by player 2.

Classes.Notes: A large octopus boss that resides in a large lava pool. In order to defeat it, the player has to fling its coconuts back against him. It shoots either three fireballs or a coconut. After the first phase, it will start to spawn Blue Podoboos. In SMG1, it will always spawn a Power Star when defeated, which requires a properly configured Scenario entry. There's also a "Spicy" variant which requires a few more hits. This variant does not spawn the long tentacles, though. If added and used in SMG2, it will crash the game when skipping the intro cutscene as the code does not account for the missing tentacles.
Classes.Name: OtaKing

SW_A.Description: If used, it remains passive while this switch is not activated. It's intended to be placed inside a TakoBarrelA or another container when using this switch. Once activated, it will hop out and behave as usual.

Classes.Notes: A green octopus boss that drives in a wheeled barrel. It can shoot multiple fireballs and coconuts from its blasters. It moves along a path, and it may stop at a path point to spit some projectiles. The fireballs create Matter Splatter holes when they land. It can be defeated by flinging coconuts against it multiple times. After defeating it, it may spawn a Power Star if the object and Scenario entry are configured correctly.

Classes.Notes: A generic planet with a model and optional collision that is meant to show fireworks. The "Fire" sound effect is synchronized with the object's particles. The normal collision mesh has the same name as the object itself. However, it also supports WaterSurface and MoveLimit collision meshes. If the model has a joint named Move, the collision will be set to follow that joint. Furthermore, it can also use particle effects and sounds. This planet supports optional Water, Indirect, Bloom, Low and Middle models as well as fur maps.

If the player isn't too close, it will pause and turn visible. It will start to wander around again if the player comes closer, though. It can be defeated using Spin Attacks, Ground Pounds, stomping, fireballs, the Rainbow power-up as well as by having Yoshi eat it. Once defeated, it will drop 20 Star Bits.

Animations must have the same name as the model in order to be played. The animations will start playing once the object loads. Also supports color change (ColorChange.brk) and texture change (TexChange.btk/.btp) animations as well as shadows (Shadow.bcsv). Lastly, it also supports an optional Bloom model.

Classes.Notes: An area that restricts the player's movement to a 2D plane while the player is inside it. The movement direction is adjusted for moving around a circular center point. Basically, this also allows the player to keep running into the direction the stick was held in first. This area may be a bit complicated to use, so it's advised to take a look at Tarantox's zone in SMG1.

Classes.Notes: A generic planet with a model and optional collision. The normal collision mesh has the same name as the object itself. However, it also supports WaterSurface and MoveLimit collision meshes. If the model has a joint named Move, the collision will be set to follow that joint. Furthermore, it can also use particle effects and sounds. Any object defined in PlanetMapDataTable usually becomes a PlanetMap object, excluding some objects. Planets support optional Water, Indirect, Bloom, Low and Middle models. In SMG2, this class supports fur maps.

Rail.Description: Lays out the vine that can be climbed.

Classes.Notes: A beanstalk-like vine that the player can swing along by shaking the Wiimote. Once the player reaches the end of the vine, it will cause them to jump off. The launch speed and angle are configurable.

Obj_arg1.Name: Number of Items

Obj_arg0.Description: The number of plants to be placed. Default is 7.

Classes.Notes: A group of decorative plants that can appear in many shapes. In SMG2, some objects of this class use ShapeModelNo to derive the proper model to be loaded. The plants attach to the nearest collision below them. If no collision is available, the individual plant may be placed at the origin of the galaxy.

Rail.Description: Lays out the vine that can be slid on.

Obj_arg1.Description: How fast the player gets launched off the vine. Default is 20.
Obj_arg1.Name: Launch Speed

Obj_arg0.Description: Invalidates clipping for all flowers while the vine is not being clipped.
Obj_arg0.Name: Invalidate Flower Clipping?

Camera.Description: Uses  while the player is sliding the vine.

Obj_arg3.Description: Specifies how much the vine bends when grabbed by the player. This also affects where the player lands. Negative values aren't allowed. Default is 15.
Obj_arg3.Name: Bending Factor

Obj_arg2.Description: At what angle the player gets launched off after reaching the end of the plant's path. Default is 25.
Obj_arg2.Name: Launch Angle

Obj_arg4.Description: If set, the player's base matrix will be calculated from the front and side vectors at the currently touched part of the vine. By default, it will be calculated from front and up vectors. This effect is barely noticeable in game.
Obj_arg4.Name: Base Matrix from Front & Side?

Classes.Notes: A vine with Star Bit Flowers that the player can slide along by grabbing onto the vine. Once the player reaches the end of the vine, it will cause them to jump off. Unlike similar objects, the player doesn't need to swing their Wiimote.

Obj_arg4.Name: Can Drown?

Classes.Notes: A strange duck-like enemy that moves around passively and chases after the player if they are nearby. It will then try to fling the player upwards. It cannot be defeated through any means, but the player can stun it using most attacks. Furthermore, it will always try to return to its initial position if it walks too far away from it. It uses a mirror model.

Obj_arg0.Name: Top not Climbable?

Camera.Description: Used when climbing the pole.

Obj_arg2.Description: Specifies the collision mesh to be used.
Obj_arg2.Name: Collision Type

Classes.Notes: A climbable pole. Pole and PoleNoModel can be climbed from all variants and the player can also climb the top part. PoleSquare and PoleSquareNoModel can be climbed from four directions and the top cannot be reached. In SMG2, Pole2Way was added which can be climbed from two directions only, so it's intended to be used in 2D-restricted sections. In SMG1, there's also code for an unfinished variant called TreeCube, but that one crashes due to missing collision. If placed in TwisterTowerGalaxy, the player will be properly removed from the pole when they touch ground.
Classes.Name: Pole

Classes.Notes: A simple decorative object with a model and collision that can be created by RailPlacementPoleObstacle or by placing it directly.

Classes.Notes: A ghostly rock boss that attacks by throwing large stones against the player. While all of them damage the player when hit, the yellow ones drop a Coin and the black ones cause a Bomb Boo to appear with which the player can attack the boss. During the second phase, the boss creates two rock hands that can be used for attacking the player and defending itself. In SMG1, it will spawn a Power Star, although this requires a properly configured Scenario entry.

Classes.Notes: A map object with a model and optional collision that usually moves on a set path and rotates along one of its axes. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RotatorRotateStart, RotatorRotateLoop, RotatorStopAtEnd, RotatorStopAtEndLoop, RotatorRotateSignStart, RotatorRotateSignLoop, RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, and RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animations Move and RailMoveSign; the latter would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior. Lastly, it can also use the stage effects Start, Moving, and Stop.
Classes.Name: RailAndRotateMoveObj

Classes.Notes: A map object with a model and optional collision that usually moves on a set path. It will activate SW_DEAD once it reaches the last path point. Additionally, it's also possible to make the platform warp to the last path point using SW_A when the platform isn't moving. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, and RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn. When it starts moving, it uses the optional effect with the name Start. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animations Move and RailMoveSign; the latter would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior. Classes.Notes: A map object with a model and optional collision that usually moves on a set path and rotates when stepped on. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, and RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn. Some sound effects depend on the used rotation type. If RotateAxis is 0, the sounds are MapPartsSeesaw1AxisRotatorBound and MapPartsSeesaw1AxisRotatorMove. If RotateAxis is 1, the only sound is MapPartsRotateLoop. If RotateAxis is 2, the only sound is MapPartsSeesaw2AxisRollerRotatorMove. The particles will emit after a random amount of frames, where the randomization interval is [Obj_arg0 - Obj_arg1, Obj_arg0 + Obj_arg1]. The particle data needs to be specified in AutoEffectList, where UniqueName matches the object's name. It can also use sound effects. EffectEmitStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts functioning. EffectEmitting specifies the looping sound effect that is played while particles are emitting.

Classes.Notes: A large rotating hammer that can crush the player. Due to the way its shadows are set up, it usually has a rotation angle of 90 degrees. It comes with a huge set of parameters, configurations and optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RotateMoveObjStart, RotateMoveObjMove, RotateMoveObjStop, Appear, RotatorRotateStart, RotatorRotateLoop, RotatorStopAtEnd, RotatorStopAtEndLoop, RotatorRotateSignStart, and RotatorRotateSignLoop. Also supports color change (ColorChange.brk) as well as texture change (TexChange.btk/.btp) animations. Lastly, it can also use the stage effects Start, Moving, and Stop.

Classes.Notes: A rotating map object with a model and optional collision that can be clipped in a Matter Splatter setup. It can also move on a path. It is also possible to configure optional sounds effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn, RotatorRotateStart, RotatorRotateLoop, RotatorStopAtEnd, RotatorStopAtEndLoop, RotatorRotateSignStart, and RotatorRotateSignLoop. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animation RailMoveSign that would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior.
Classes.Name: RotateMoveObjClipParts

RotateStopTime.Description: The force used to restore its original rotation after getting of the platform. Only used if RotateAxis is 0 or 1.
RotateStopTime.Name: Restore Force

Values.Notes: Rotate around Z axis, returns to original rotation
Rotate XZ plane, returns to original rotation

Classes.Notes: A seesaw-like platform that rotates when stepped on. Unlike SimpleSeesawObj, it uses two particle effects named Wait and Move that won't be rotated. It supports three rotation modes. Furthermore, it can use optional sound effects. If RotateAxis is 0, the sounds are MapPartsSeesaw1AxisRotatorBound and MapPartsSeesaw1AxisRotatorMove. If RotateAxis is 1, the only sound is MapPartsRotateLoop. If RotateAxis is 2, the only sound is MapPartsSeesaw2AxisRollerRotatorMove.

Classes.Notes: A strange boss that throws large sand boulders or bombs to attack the player. Sometimes, it opens its large mouth which the player needs to attack with fireballs in order to defeat it. During the second phase, it creates two large cannons that shoot more obstacles. Once defeated, it will spawn a Power Star. However, this requires a properly configured Scenario entry. If SW_APPEAR is not used, the boss battle will start immediately.

The scoring controller (ScoreAttackCounter) that specifies the minimum score and time limit needs to be added as a separate object. Classes.Notes: A stationary clam enemy that opens and closes its valves periodically. Usually, it contains an item inside that the player can collect. It may damage the player by closing its valves. The game supports variants containing a Coin or a Star Chip. The class also contains code for ShellfishBlueChip and ShellfishKinokoOneUp who contain a Blue Chip and a 1-Up Mushroom, respectively. However, the 1-Up Mushroom variant does not work properly as the item is always invisible. When hit with a Koopa Shell, it will open its valves and become stunned for a few seconds.

Classes.Notes: A basic object that can be destroyed through various means. Unlike other variants, it comes with an additional collision mesh named Break that will be used after destroying it. The supported methods to destroy a certain object are hard-coded. It needs the animation Break.bck that will be used when the object gets destroyed. In addition, it also supports an optional visibility animation called Break.bva. Finally, it may use sound or particle effects when it gets destroyed. These go by the names MapObjActorBreak and Break, respectively.

SW_B.Description: If used, the object will move only while this switch is activated.

SW_A.Description: If used, the collision will be enabled if and only if this switch is activated.

Point_arg1.Description: The time in frames it takes for the object to reach the movement speed set at this point.
Point_arg1.Name: Acceleration Time

Point_arg0.Description: The movement speed the object has starting from this point. If Point_arg7 is set to 1, this specifies the time in frames it takes to reach the next point.
Point_arg0.Name: Movement Speed / Time

SW_DEAD.Description: Can be activated when the object is killed through a cutscene action.

RotateAxis.Description: The object's axis to rotate around.
RotateAxis.Name: Rotation Axis

RotateAccelType.Description: Decides whether RotateSpeed specifies the rotation speed, acceleration, or the time it takes to rotate to the specified angle.

Values.Notes: RotateSpeed specifies time until desired angle

RotateAccelType.Name: Rotation Speed Type

Point_arg5.Description: The time in frames the object waits at this point before it continues moving again.
Point_arg5.Name: Stop Time

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Values.Notes: Start at nearest position on path

SW_PARAM.Description: The rotation speed is adjusted with ParamScale while this switch is activated.

Path_arg5.Description: If used, the object stays at its original position and moves to its actual position on the path. This setting specifies how fast the object snaps back into its original position. The higher the value is, the slower it moves.
Path_arg5.Name: Snapping Speed

RotateStopTime.Description: The time in frames it takes to restart rotation after stopping.
RotateStopTime.Name: Restart Delay

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

Point_arg7.Description: Decides whether Point_arg0 specifies the movement speed or the time it takes to reach the next point.

Values.Notes: Point_arg0 specifies time until next point

Point_arg7.Name: Speed Type

RotateSpeed.Description: How fast the object rotates. If RotateAccelType is set to 2, this specifies the time in frames it takes to rotate to the specified angle.
RotateSpeed.Name: Rotation Speed / Time

SignMotionType.Description: Specifies whether the object will shake before it starts moving or not.
SignMotionType.Name: Shake Start Type

Rail.Description: The path that it moves on.

RotateType.Description: Specifies how the object should continue rotating after reaching the targeted angle.
RotateType.Name: Rotation Type

RotateAngle.Description: How many degrees it rotates. If RotateAccelType is not 2, 0 equals 360 which means it will rotate indefinitely.
RotateAngle.Name: Rotation Angle

Path_arg1.Description: How the object behaves once it reaches the last path point.
Path_arg1.Name: Movement Type

Path_arg2.Description: Specifies whether the orange indicator dots should be used and how they are displayed.

Values.Notes: Draw dots but disappear one by one when passed by
Use bigger dots for path points

Path_arg2.Name: Indicator Dots Type

Classes.Notes: A map object with a model and optional collision that can be clipped in a Matter Splatter setup. It can also move on a path and rotate along its own axes. It can use optional sound effects whose names are self-explanatory: RailMoverStop, RailMoverWaitStart, RailMoverWaitStartMove, RailMoverRestartAtEnd, RailMoverWaiting, RailMoverMoveStart, RailMoverMoveLoop, RailMoverSignStart, RailMoverSignLoop, RailMoverStopAtPoint, RailMoverStopAtPointAfter, RailMoverStopAtPointLoop, RailMoverStopAtEnd, RailMoverStopAtEndAfter, RailMoverStopAtEndLoop, RailMoverStopAtEndWithPlayerOn, RotatorRotateStart, RotatorRotateLoop, RotatorStopAtEnd, RotatorStopAtEndLoop, RotatorRotateSignStart, and RotatorRotateSignLoop. Furthermore, it also supports the optional animation RailMoveSign that would be used when SignMotionType is set to a value representing the shaking behavior.
Classes.Name: SimpleClipPartsObj

Classes.Notes: A generic particles effect with a clipping radius of 500 units and a far clipping distance of 50 meters. The particle data needs to be specified in AutoEffectList, where UniqueName matches the object's name. It can also use sound effects. EffectEmitStart specifies the sound effect used when it starts functioning. EffectEmitting specifies the looping sound effect that is played while particles are emitting.

Classes.Notes: A platform that sinks when the player steps on it. Once the player gets off of this platform, it rises up again. It can also use optional sound effects. The sound names are self-explanatory: MapPartsFloaterMoveUpEnd, MapPartsFloaterRidden, MapPartsFloaterMoveDown, and MapPartsFloaterMoveUp. Furthermore, it can use effects with the name Ripple that will appear at the object's original position.

Classes.Notes:
A variant of SimpleMapObj. This is a generic map object with a model, collision and looping particle effect. The UniqueName effect types that can be specified are EffectEmitStart and EffectEmitStart. If the object is called PeachCastleMeteor, it will ignore clipping checks.
It also supports BCK, BTK, BTP, BRK and BVA animations. Animations must have the same name as the model in order to be played. The animations will start playing once the object loads. Classes.Notes: A seesaw-like platform that rotates when stepped on. It supports two (SMG1) / three (SMG2) rotation modes. Furthermore, it can use optional sound effects. Classes.Notes: Sets up the ending credits by creating and registering several objects as well as the scrolling text. The objects StaffRollSky, StaffRollDecorateFaceShip, StaffRollDecorateComet and PeachCastleNightPlanet need to be linked to it. Further, it uses nine GeneralPos positions to specify the player's position during the cycles. The GeneralPos instances also specify the background (BVA frame) from StaffRollSky to be used during the individual cycles. If the player has collected 120 Power Stars, the epilogue sequence (ChildRoomGalaxy) will be initiated.

Classes.Notes: A Silver Star that is trapped in a bubble. It can be collected by popping the bubble. It should be linked to a proper CollectTico instance using ParentID (SMG1) / GeneratorId (SMG2).

Classes.Notes: A spider enemy that hangs from a thread of webbing. When the player is nearby, it will drop and swing back and forth on their threads to damage the player. They can be defeated using most of the player's attacks, explosions and objects like Stretch Plants. They can drop a Coin or three Star Bits.
Classes.Name: StringSpider

SW_AWAKE.Description: Enables rendering and resumes updates when this switch is active.

SW_APPEAR.Description: Appears when this switch is activated.

Classes.Notes: An area that defeats Boos and removes the Boo power-up from the player if they are not covered by "Sunshade" collision meshes. SunshadeMapParts is the only class of objects that supports these collision meshes. Thus, the area cannot be properly utilized in SMG2.
Classes.Name: SunLightArea

SW_B.Description: Activated or deactivated depending on the used event flow node.

Message.Description: The text dialogue's label formats are SuperDreamer%03d and SuperDreamerEnd%03d, where %03d is the text message ID. If set to -1, the default dialogue from SceneCommonMessage will be used.

YoshiTargetable.Description: Can be targeted and licked by Yoshi.

Classes.Notes: A cosmic variant of Rosalina that offers players to beat the level for them. However, the spirit will only appear if SW_APPEAR is activated or if the player failed the selected mission a set amount of times. The PAD data used to simulate player input can be found in the pad folder of the Galaxy's Ghost archive.

Obj_arg7.Description: The index of this Launch Star's path that is used for updating the segment of the flight path that should be rendered. Useless in SMG2 since this feature is dummied-out in that game.

SW_B.Description: Once activated, the Launch Star will disappear. If the switch gets deactivated again, it will reappear.

Object spawns if it has already appeared before dying
